questions.question: What does CSS stand for?
questions.answer: Cascading Style Sheets.

questions.question: What is a CSS rule made of?
questions.answer: A selector and a declaration block (property: value pairs).

questions.question: What is the difference between a class and an id selector?
questions.answer: A class can be reused; an id should be unique on a page.

questions.question: How do you select an element by id in CSS?
questions.answer: Use #idName (e.g., #header).

questions.question: How do you select elements by class in CSS?
questions.answer: Use .className (e.g., .card).

questions.question: What does the “cascading” part of CSS mean?
questions.answer: When multiple rules match, CSS resolves conflicts using specificity, importance, and source order.

questions.question: What is specificity?
questions.answer: A scoring system that decides which selector wins when multiple rules apply.

questions.question: Which is more specific: .btn or button?
questions.answer: .btn is more specific than the element selector button.

questions.question: What does !important do?
questions.answer: It forces a declaration to win over others (except other !important with higher specificity).

questions.question: What is the default display value for a <div>?
questions.answer: block.

questions.question: What is the CSS box model?
questions.answer: Content + padding + border + margin.

questions.question: What does box-sizing: border-box do?
questions.answer: Width/height include padding and border (content box shrinks accordingly).

questions.question: What’s the difference between margin and padding?
questions.answer: Margin is space outside the border; padding is space inside the border.

questions.question: What does overflow: hidden do?
questions.answer: Clips content that overflows the element’s box.

questions.question: What units are commonly used in CSS?
questions.answer: px, %, em, rem, vw, vh.

questions.question: What is the difference between em and rem?
questions.answer: em is relative to the element (or parent) font-size; rem is relative to the root font-size.

questions.question: What does max-width do?
questions.answer: It limits the element’s width so it can’t grow beyond that value.

questions.question: What does min-height do?
questions.answer: It ensures the element is at least that tall, even if content is smaller.

questions.question: What’s the difference between visibility: hidden and display: none?
questions.answer: visibility:hidden keeps layout space; display:none removes the element from layout.

questions.question: What does opacity: 0 do?
questions.answer: Makes the element fully transparent but it still takes space and can receive events unless changed.

questions.question: What does display: flex do?
questions.answer: Turns an element into a flex container and lays out its children with flex rules.

questions.question: How do you center items horizontally in flexbox?
questions.answer: Use justify-content: center on the flex container.

questions.question: How do you center items vertically in flexbox?
questions.answer: Use align-items: center on the flex container (for a single row).

questions.question: What is the main axis in flexbox?
questions.answer: The direction items flow, controlled by flex-direction.

questions.question: What does flex-wrap do?
questions.answer: Allows items to wrap onto multiple lines instead of staying on one line.

questions.question: What does display: grid do?
questions.answer: Creates a grid container for 2D layout with rows and columns.

questions.question: How do you define grid columns?
questions.answer: With grid-template-columns (e.g., repeat(3, 1fr)).

questions.question: What is position: relative used for?
questions.answer: It positions the element relative to its normal spot and creates a containing block for absolutely positioned children.

questions.question: What is position: absolute relative to?
questions.answer: Its nearest positioned ancestor (non-static), otherwise the initial containing block/page.

questions.question: What does z-index control?
questions.answer: Stacking order of positioned elements within the same stacking context.

questions.question: What is the descendant selector?
questions.answer: A space, e.g., .card p selects p inside .card.

questions.question: What is the child selector?
questions.answer: >, e.g., .list > li selects direct children only.

questions.question: What does :hover do?
questions.answer: Applies styles when the user hovers over an element.

questions.question: What does :focus do?
questions.answer: Applies styles when an element is focused (e.g., input selected).

questions.question: What does :active do?
questions.answer: Applies styles while an element is being activated (e.g., mouse down).

questions.question: What does :nth-child(n) select?
questions.answer: Elements based on their position among siblings (e.g., :nth-child(2) is the 2nd child).

questions.question: What is a pseudo-element?
questions.answer: A keyword like ::before or ::after that styles a part of an element.

questions.question: How do you create a pseudo-element content?
questions.answer: Use ::before/::after with the content property (e.g., content: '' ).

questions.question: What does attribute selector [type="text"] do?
questions.answer: Selects elements with type="text" (e.g., <input type="text">).

questions.question: What’s the difference between :first-child and :first-of-type?
questions.answer: :first-child is the first child of its parent; :first-of-type is the first of that element type.

questions.question: What is SCSS?
questions.answer: A Sass syntax that is a superset of CSS with variables, nesting, mixins, etc.

questions.question: What are SCSS variables used for?
questions.answer: To reuse values like colors and spacing (e.g., $primary: #6366f1;).

questions.question: What is nesting in SCSS?
questions.answer: Writing selectors inside selectors to reflect hierarchy (use sparingly).

questions.question: What is a mixin in SCSS?
questions.answer: A reusable block of styles that can take parameters (@mixin / @include).

questions.question: What is @include used for?
questions.answer: To apply a mixin inside a selector.

questions.question: What is the difference between a mixin and a function in SCSS?
questions.answer: Mixins output CSS; functions return a value.

questions.question: What is @extend used for?
questions.answer: To share selector rules by extending another selector (can increase selector complexity).

questions.question: What is a partial in Sass/SCSS?
questions.answer: A file starting with _ (underscore) meant to be imported into other files.

questions.question: What does @use do in modern Sass?
questions.answer: Loads a Sass module with namespacing (preferred over legacy @import).

questions.question: Does SCSS run in the browser?
questions.answer: No, it’s compiled to CSS during build time.
